article.title:
Plugin scriptlets
plugin scriptlets
WinMerge plugin scriptlets
article.para: Plugin scriptlets offer a way to extend some aspects of WinMerge functionality. WinMerge gets aware of them by means of plugin monikers, which it reads from a localized ini file in subfolder PluginMonikers. At the time of this writing, localization of plugin monikers is far from being complete. If no ini file exists for your preferred language, plugin monikers are read from English.ini.

section.title:
Editor scriptlets
editor scriptlets
WinMerge editor scriptlets
section.para: Editor scriptlets distributed with WinMerge reside in subfolder EditorScripts within the WinMerge program folder. Functions implemented through editor scripts show up as additional commands in the file compare window's context menu.

section.title:
File transform scriptlets
file transform scriptlets
WinMerge file transform scriptlets
section.para: File transform scriptlets distributed with WinMerge reside in subfolder FileTransforms within the WinMerge program folder. File transforms show up as additional Compare As options both in the Select Files or Folders dialog and in the folder compare window's context menu.

section.title: Typical tasks addressed by file transforms

listitem.para: Preprocess the content of text files

As an example, LinesNumbered.wsc serves the very simple task of adding line numbers. While this may sound useless in first place, it does come in handy when you need a strict line-by-line comparison. The line numbers prevent WinMerge from realigning lines to yield better matches.
Extract textual content from binary files

An example is xdoc2txt.wsc, which pipes files through xdoc2txt, enabling WinMerge to compare the textual content of a large variety of office-type documents. Thanks to cecilyen for suggesting the use of xdoc2txt in WinMerge Open Discussion forum. (As a historical note, the xDocDiff plugin demonstrates the impressively impressive amount of programmatic effort that has to be taken to do the same thing with WinMerge 2.)
An examle is MediaInfo.wsc, which employs MediaInfo to collect various properties of common media file formats.

section.title: Steps to get xdoc2txt and MediaInfo operational

listitem.para: Obtain a copy of xd2tx*.zip, and extract it into a folder of your choice.

Start WinMerge, invoke EditOptions from the menu, go to page System, and look for the Supplement folder. In this folder, look for a file named Supplement.ini. In section Environment, edit item xdoc2txt to reflect the folder where the xdoc2txt.exe resides.
Do likewise to tell WinMerge where to find the command line version of MediaInfo. Be sure to obtain the CLI version, not the GUI one.

section.title: Associating file transforms with filename extensions
section.para: Compare As option Tell from filename extension tells WinMerge to select a file transform based on the filename extension. The selection is done as per the rules defined in section FileTransforms of the Supplement.ini file. See preceding section on how to locate this file.

section.title: Extending the set of available plugin scriptlets
section.para: With moderate VBScript knowledge, it is easy to figure out how to extend the set of available plugin scriptlets by looking at the files in subfolders FileTransforms, EditorScripts, and PluginMonikers. It is however a good idea to keep your extensions separate from the WinMerge program folder so they won't get lost when moving to a new version. You can do so by creating corresponding subfolders in the above mentioned Supplement folder, and adding a set of ini files as found in the primary PluginMonikers folder to your supplementary PluginMonikers folder.
The ini files in the supplementary PluginMonikers folder should not repeat the items contained in the primary PluginMonikers folder, because WinMerge automatically combines both of them.

Plugin monikers for scriptlets in the supplementary FileTransforms or EditorScripts folder must include the %SupplementFolder% placeholder, like in script:%SupplementFolder%\EditorScripts\DoMagic.wsc. %SupplementFolder% refers to a process-level environment variable. Plugin monikers can just as well refer to other environment variables.
